encyclopedia_tutorial_video_subtitle_tex.text:
The fate of your clan is decided on the battlefield.
You'll need a strong command of your troops, along with

a mastery of their strengths, weaknesses and special abilities.
In this tutorial we will cover the fundamentals of managing
an army on the battlefield, providing the foundations for victory.

An initial survey of the battlefield is crucial to planning tactics,
so let's get familiar with the camera first.

We can change our view of the battlefield by using
the WASD keys, with the Q and E keys rotating our view.

Scroll the mouse wheel and we can zoom in on our forces.
Double clicking a unit or its unit card, centres and
zooms the camera on its field of view.

We’re in the opening stage of a battle right now – the deployment phase.
At this point, we can tweak the position of our army by moving

our units to locations within the outlined deployment zone. This planning
stage is a feature of every battle, unless we’re surprised
by an enemy ambush on the campaign map.

We need to select a unit before we can change its position.
We can either left-click on the unit itself, or on its unit card.

Now we can instantly place it by right-clicking on a new location.
Once the battle starts, we'll use this same method to issue move orders.

Let's widen the line of this unit. With the unit selected,
we hold down the right-mouse button and drag the mouse.

We can also alter the depth of a unit and its facing in the same way.
The manoeuvre compass allows us to fine tune unit positioning that little bit more.

Let's start the battle and look to seize the initiative.
As the attacker, we need to defeat our enemy;

the defending army can merely hold their ground and repel our attacks.
We're the aggressor here, so we should quickly move our units to engage.

Let's pick up the pace! By double right-clicking a location, we can order our
units to run and make up the ground at double speed.

We need to be wary however - running units too often,
particularly uphill, will tire them out.

If we want to give multiple movement orders for a unit,
we can use waypoints to set a path.

We'll hold down shift and right-click on several points on the battlefield.
Now our selected unit will follow that route,
moving to each location in turn.

Enough posturing, it's time to engage! The enemy have a unit of Yari Kachi
split away from their main army - let's pick them off.

We’ll send in our Katana Kachi to face them, their swords
and superior melee skills should overwhelm the enemy.
We'll select our unit and right-click on our target to order the attack.

If we charge an enemy at speed, our attack will be more devastating.
That’s particularly true when attacking with cavalry units.
Let’s round up our Yari Ki cavalry and look to smash the enemy line.

By double right-clicking on an enemy, we'll order our cavalry to charge
and the impact will inflict more damage. Charging spear units

with cavalry is never a good idea, but if we attack the enemy's flank or rear,
it will be far more effective than engaging them head-on.

Our cavalry charge was devastating! The white bar above
the enemy banner indicates that the unit has routed.

This occurs when the morale of a unit is broken.
Heavy casualties, exposure to an enemy on the flank or rear,
or the untimely death of their General, can all damage a unit's morale.

Morale can be maintained in a number of ways. Proximity to friendly
units is important, while a nearby General can also be a major factor.

A General has a number of special abilities that can quickly boost
the morale of a unit, even when the odds are stacked against them.

Other units also have special abilities – their controls are always
located near the manoeuvre compass. Some abilities can only be used sparingly;

they have “cooldown" times which will limit how often you can
bring them into play.

Groups and formations can really help to organsie our troops efficiently.
They also enable us to issue orders to multiple units.

Let's create a group now. We can left-click and drag a box around our units,
or hold down the Control key and select units one by one.

With our units selected, we'll press the “G” key or click the Group button,
to set up the group.

We can now issue orders to our group and place it in one of several
formations.With our group locked in our chosen formation,

they'll now attempt to hold their shape and spacing whilst carrying out
move orders.

We’ve engaged the enemy hand-to-hand, but we also have a variety of
western-inspired firepower at our disposal, capable of cutting down an

enemy from range. Let’s select our Line Infantry and start to use some of
that firepower now.

Our Line Infantry carry rifles. They are a direct fire unit that need
a clear line of sight on their enemy to be effective.

While bowmen can fire over obstacles, rifle units need to be positioned
carefully to give them a clear field of fire. That arc drawn
in front of our unit shows their firing range.

Artillery units offer us even more firepower.Our guns can be
attached or “limbered” to horses and pulled around the battlefield.

Once unlimbered, they can be used to inflict heavy casualties on
approaching enemies. They're also very handy when it comes to
destroying wall defences in sieges.

These Gatling guns are our most fearsome artillery weapon.
Let’s use them on the advancing enemy!

With the unit selected, we can choose to either target enemy troops directly,
or focus fire on any area of the battlefield,

creating a kill zone that will help block a would-be advance.
Either way, any unit who ventures within range will be quickly shot to pieces!

In this tutorial we’ll cover the basics of the camera, the
deployment and movement of ships and the knowledge you
need to sink the enemy.

Let's scan the battle area first. We can change our view by
using the WASD keys, with the Q and E keys rotating the camera.

If we scroll the mouse-wheel, we can zoom closer to our ships.
Double clicking a ship or its card, centres and zooms the camera
on its field of view.

Before a battle we must deploy our fleet. At this point, we can
position our ships anywhere within the outlined zone.

Placing and positioning ships is simple – just left-click on a ship
to select, then right-click a location to drop it down.

We can also change a ship's heading. With a ship selected
and the right mouse button held down, we move the the mouse right

and left until we get the angle we’re after. Release the
mouse button to set the new heading.

Let's click "Start Battle" to end the deployment and reveal
the enemy fleet. They’re already closing on us, so we should start positioning

our ships to engage. To manoeuvere a ship we just left-click to select,
then right-click on our chosen location.

We need to keep one step ahead of the enemy. Let's take a
look at the movement controls available. Using these, we can

increase this ship’s speed, rotate the direction and back
our ship out of trouble.

Engaging with the enemy is simple, we'll select our ship and
right-click on our target. It will then manoeuvre towards them
and, once in range, will open fire.

Using the fire-at-will button, we can also set a ship to attack
any enemy that comes within range. This arc represents the
targeting range of our ship's guns.

Get a broadside on the enemy and we can quickly turn
the tide of battle. If our guns can get a clear sight of the

enemy hull, we can deal some serious damage. Let’s get in close
and manoeuvre to give our gunners the best possible angle of attack.

Here’s our chance! With full guns on the enemy, we'll take manual
control by selecting the broadside button. Our firing arc is

smaller now – indicating that we need to be at close range for
a broadside to be effective. Closing on the enemy is risky,
but a devastating broadside makes it worthwhile!

Our guns are fully loaded! Let's click the broadside button
again to open fire. The enemy have suffered the full
force of our firepower; we've ripped through their hull!

Our ship is carrying an array of shell types, effective against
a variety of enemies. We change shell types for the selected
ship using these buttons.

Up until now we’ve been firing solid cast iron shells, they’re
effective enough, but let's change to explosive shells so we can
deal more damage to wooden hulls.

We need to change our strategy again for ironclads. A well
aimed broadside with armour piercing shells will do the trick!

Our direct hit has cut through that ship's hull! It's also made a
serious dent on the crew's morale. They've taken heavy casualties

and are badly shaken. If we can inflict further damage, they
may flee or surrender; either way, that would take them out of

the battle. That’s the key to victory - we don’t need to sink every
ship to win this engagement.

The enemy are fighting back! One of our ships has taken
damage and we should look to repair it.

We'll double left-click on the ship to zoom the camera and
assess matters. With the ship selected, we can use the repair

button to issue the order. This ship needs protection while
our crew are at work. It won't be able move or retaliate,
so it’s an easy target.

Let's bring more of our forces into battle. By using groups, we
can issue commands to more than one ship and place them
in formation to maximise firepower.

To group some ships, we simply left-click and drag a box
around them, then click the "Group button". Let's group our

entire fleet. Now we can order our fleet to close
and overwhelm the enemy.

Victory is ours! The enemy have been broken and sunk.
We're free to plunder the spoils.

Victory on the open battlefields will keep our enemies in
check, but we'll need to master the art of siege battles before we can

take their lands. Sieges demand new strategies from the
attacker and the defending force.

In this encounter, we’re charged with taking the enemy castle;
a fiercely defended stronghold that will test our men and our tactics.

As we learned in the land battle essentials tutorial, we'll
spend the deployment phase setting up our army, forming groups
and setting formations for the assault on the walls.

Our objective, as the attacker, is to capture the keep or “tenshu”
located in the centre of the castle. We can also win by

annihilating the defending force. Our troops need to battle
their way through the defences to get to the enemy, so
we'll need to breach those castle walls.

Artillery is crucial. With cannon in our ranks, we can target the
outer walls and have our men break through their defences.

With our cannon selected and in range, we'll right-click a
wall area to target fire.

There's another way we can overcome the walls: our Ninja and
infantry units can be ordered to scale them. We'll also order
our cavalry units to dismount and make the climb.

With a unit selected, we'll choose an area of the outer wall to
attack. Notice that our cursor changes; this tells us that this unit
can climb here.

Any infantry unit can climb a wall but heavily armoured troops
are slower. They're more likely to suffer casualties as a result.

Ninjas come into their own here. Their agility and light armour make
short work of scaling the wall and they're equipped with
climbing claws, designed for the task at hand.

The enemy are well positioned. We're taking heavy causalities
before our men can get a foothold on the battlements!

Let's try to split the enemy forces by ordering our men to climb
some undefended areas.

Our men are under fire from those towers! Once we're inside the
walls, we should move quickly to capture them. If we order

a unit into the marked area surrounding a tower, it will eventually
fall under our control. We can then turn that hail of fire on the enemy.

We can capture and gain control of the gatehouse in
the same way. Now we've seized the main gate, we'll order

our cavalry to flood into the castle and slaughter the
remaining defenders!

With the outer defences breached, let's edge our men towards
the inner wall and head for the tenshu. Capture that, and the

battle will be won. The castle and the campaign province will
be ours for the taking!

The objective in the campaign is to banish our enemies
from the map by defeating their forces and capturing their lands.

To achieve this, we'll need to manage our provinces wisely,
build our economy and recruit powerful armies. The campaign is

turn-based, with each turn the equivalent of two weeks in
the game. When we’ve made all our moves, we click
the End Turn button to progress.

Our armies are crucial to our success – we'll use them
to defend our lands, defeat our enemies and capture provinces.

An army is made up of individual units of troops
that we recruit. They cost money to build and maintain,
so we need to keep them busy to justify their upkeep.

Let's add some more units to our army.
We can recruit and reinforce armies from any of our cities.

The buildings present in a city decide the type and
quality of units available and can include cavalry, artillery and infantry.

Left-clicking a unit type, adds it to our recruitment queue.
It may take a number of turns before the unit becomes available.

Let's mobilise our new recruits. By holding shift we can
select our units by using left-click, then we can
right-click outside of the city to form a new army.

Without a General in charge, this army will lack leadership
and organisation. Let’s merge them with our existing army
and bring them under the command of its General.

An enemy army has formed nearby. We must protect our
provinces from any threat; if all our regions should fall,
our campaign comes to an end.

Let’s push them back with the General’s army.
Notice that when we mouse over, a circular border is drawn

out on the map; this is the army’s “zone of control”.
Enemies are unable to enter this zone without first attacking our army.
That’s useful to remember when selecting strategic locations on the map.

Let’s approach the enemy. With our army selected, we simply
right-click a location on the map to issue the

order to move. We can press spacebar to speed up movement on the campaign
map. Right-clicking on an opposing army will move our forces to
engage and instigate a battle.

This pre-battle panel offers an overview of the two armies involved.
The balance of power meter shows how we compare to
the enemy so we can make a decision on our next move.

We’ve got several options here. We can choose to command our
forces on the 3D battlemap, withdraw our army and regroup,

or fight out this encounter using the auto-resolve function.
We’ll choose the latter.

The enemy are crushed and here we’re presented with the
full glory of our victory. This panel shows our

casualties and the enemy's losses. Notice that, having survived
the battle, our units have gained experience; they will now

be more effective in the field. Experienced units should be nurtured.
They will become precious as our campaign develops.

The enemy have a city nearby that looks relatively undefended, if we can seize it,
we'll gain a valuable province.

Right-clicking on the enemy city presents us with some
pre-battle options. A siege offers a new choice:

we can look to starve out the population, maintaining the siege
for a number of turns until we gain a peaceful surrender.

But we’ll choose to put our enemy out of their misery here;
let’s auto-resolve.

Their resistance was futile! The enemy city is ours for
the taking. Now we can choose to ruthlessly loot the

city of its wealth, request that it becomes our vassal,
or occupy it peacefully.

Let’s get a better view of our prize. Double left-clicking
on the city opens the province details panel.

Here we can check on the wealth and growth it's currently
generating. Right now however, we’ve a small matter of public unrest
to deal with.

When we capture a province, particularly if we choose to loot it's wealth,
we will often need to calm the dissent created by our arrival
before we can reap the rewards.

Money talks. If we choose to exempt this province from taxation,
its people will soon forgive their new masters and public order
will be restored – at least for now.

A strong military presence can also help matters. If we
recruit some further units and leave them garrisoned here,
they will help stamp out protests and stave off rebellions.

We need to stay wary – if public order declines again,
we will risk a full-scale rebellion and that
could threaten to bring production in this province to a halt.

There's more we can do more to improve public order.
We can construct buildings that offer services to keep

the population appeased. We also need to consider developing our
city to bolster our coffers and advance our armies.

Building an Inn will help earn us more income and
boost growth in the province. Selecting the Inn

from the building panel, let's issue the construction order. Like
recruitment, we may have to wait a number of turns
before the building is available.

Finances improved, we now need to build up our forces.
We have armed citizenry in the city, but they'll
only provide limited protection and can't be used to help us conquer new lands.

Improving military buildings will enable us to recruit more advanced
units. We need to remember that, as our armies are reinforced,

they become more expensive to maintain. We need to balance
economic growth with military expansion, whilst also keeping public order in check.

It’s a delicate balance but when we manage and develop
each of these elements, our provinces will enjoy growth,

our armies will become more powerful and we can then
look to expand our borders further. Achieve this,
and we can walk the path to victory.

In this second campaign tutorial, we’ll look at expanding our naval
capabilities, modernising our clan to advance technologies, recruiting agents and
building relationships with rival clans through diplomacy.

Armies are vital to our clan’s expansion, but if we can
also build a strong navy, we can control profitable trade routes
and provide military support to our ground forces.

Ships and their crews are recruited at ports, in much the same
way as units from cities. Left-clicking on a port displays

the recruitment tab. From here, we simply left-click to add
a ship to the queue. Like units, it may take a number
of turns before the ship is available.

We can use ships to help us transport our armies and characters.
With an army selected, we'll right-click on our ship

to order them aboard. Once we’ve sailed to our destination,
we right-click again on a location on the map to disembark.

We can use fleets of ships to cripple enemy trade by raiding
their routes and blockading their ports. With our fleet selected,

let's right-click on this enemy port and choose to attack.
Our fleet will now sail into the port, halting the profitable trade
running through it.

A strong navy can also offer substantial military support. If we can
get our fleet positioned close to an enemy settlement or army,

they can lend their firepower to assist our land forces. Here we
can see our ship’s bombardment radius; any enemy within this

is vulnerable to our guns. Let's right-click the enemy city
to issue the attack order.

We need to be wary of coastal defences. If an enemy develops
their ports, they can build gun batteries to protect against naval invasion.

Move a fleet within range of these guns and we’ll suffer damage.
Of course, we can also upgrade our ports and construct similar
defences to protect our own coastlines.

Clicking the Clan Development button opens a panel showing all the
technologies we can research to further our clan.

This shows our current level of modernisation. Improving our civic buildings
and infrastructure throughout our provinces, will increase
modernisation further, opening up new technologies.

There are two branches of technology available: civil policy and military
technologies. The latter can unlock new weapons, troop types and special abilities.

Researching civil policy will improve our clan’s infrastructure and economy.
Let's left-click a technology to begin. Technologies take a number
of turns to research.

The Clan Management panel offers us a view of our progress.
Here we can check on our victory conditions, assess our
reputation and relationships with other clans and manage our family and council.

The Family and Council Panel allows us to assign positions of
responsibility to family members, handing them commissions to help our war effort

and civic development. When sons come of age, they automatically become
Generals. Daughters meanwhile, can be married off, helping to extend

our bloodline. Their hand in marriage can also be offered to help improve
diplomatic relations.

We can also switch our clan's allegiance on this panel. At the
beginning of the campaign, our clan is allied to either the

Emperor or the Shogun, but this can be changed once during
a Daimyo’s lifetime. This decision can't be taken lightly. Switching allegiance
can disrupt public order and damage our Daimyo’s reputation.

Our clan's fame level increses as we win battles and conquer
provinces. As we become stronger and more renowned, we’ll be given a

title to represent our new status. We need to monitor our
reputation carefully. Once our clan is perceived to be too powerful,

we’ll be forced to declare our intentions. At this stage we must
either swear our allegiance to the Emperor or Shogun, or look to
unify Japan under our own rule.

There's other ways we can interact with rival clans on the campaign
map. Agents allow us to undermine our enemies with guile and cunning.

They can also be recruited at our cities in the same way as units.
The buildings present in a city dictate the type of agent
we can recruit.

Agents earn experience as the campaign progresses, enabling us to upgrade
their talents and abilities. Each Agent type has their own unique

skill tree, so we can nurture them and create specialists in a
particular role.

Let's use an agent now. With our Geisha selected,
right-clicking on an enemy army, character or city, presents us

with a variety of actions. Agents also offer bonuses to our
own clan. The charms of our Geisha are helping to boost
public order in this province.

While we're looking to destroy rival clans, maintaining
relations to gain allies and trade partners, also works in our favour.

This map on the Diplomacy Panel displays the current attitude
of surrounding provinces to our clan. Red indicates hostility;

provinces in green view us more favourably. We can get the same
view for any of the clans we’ve met by selecting them to change
the map display.

Let's open negotiations with a rival clan. Note our current
relationship status; this will have a major bearing on our talks.

Once negotiations begin, we can then build offers and demands
and counter any offers made to us via this panel.

Establishing trade agreements can be particularly lucrative
and help us build buoyant economy. We can view our

current trading partners via the Finance Panel. Here we see the
current prices for resources, together with our trade
partners and the goods being imported and exported.

The control of resources can be crucial. Some buildings and
units require a specific resource before they can be

obtained. We can look to conquer lands to gain control of resources,
but we can use trade to collect them without spilling blood.

By upgrading our ports, we can open up lucrative trade
routes with western powers, providing a huge boost

to our coffers. These precious trade routes will be prime targets
for enemy raids. We'll need to build and maintain a military
presence to guard them.

You now have the knowledge you need to begin conquering your
enemies in the campaign. For futher guidance, look to use the
tooltips, the advisors and the in-game encyclopaedia.

Fall of the Samurai’s campaign can be played in multiplayer against
an opponent. There’s also an “Avatar Conquest” mode that provides

a backdrop for multiplayer battles. In this tutorial we’ll explore
this mode, join an online clan and fight for supremacy under
their banner.

We'll start by creating our own General to lead our men in battle.
We can modify this “Avatar” as we play. Our avatar will level up, earn
new skills, armour sets, and powerful followers and objects called “Retainers”.

We'll name our avatar and customise his look. On this screen we can
assign armour and equipment pieces that are collected
as we play. We can change the colour scheme of all these pieces.

Our Avatar also needs a banner. There are multiple designs of “Mon”
to choose from, and a full range of colours for us to play with.

We'll also choose a starting province here. Each province has its
own unique benefits; we can click on each one to view the details.

On the avatar screen we can choose to edit our banner, customise
our avatar and equipment and get a view on current progress

towards our next level. We can also see the traits we’ve gained and
our chosen retainers for the next battle.

The Army Management screen is where we build our army. As the
game progresses, we’ll collect a roster of regular and veteran

units. Right now, we've limited unit types available, but a few victories
will quickly improve our options .

Units have costs assigned to them and, initially, we have a limited budget
to spend. Let’s use this now to create our starting army.

We simply drag a unit from our roster to add it to our army. Once
we’re done, we can save the army setup so we can
keep it for future battles.

The Avatar Conquest map provides the backdrop for all our battles.
Here we’ll fight for ownership of provinces and sea regions.

As we contest and win battles, we’ll gain rewards and upgrades for our
avatar and our armies.

Let's choose our first province. Holding the left mouse button
with our avatar piece selected, we'll drag it into one of the highlighted provinces.
This province now becomes the prize for victory in our next battle.

Let’s fight our first multiplayer battle. We can choose to join
any of the existing battles out there, or host our own.
We can access these options via the Battle List button.

When we host our own battle, we can use this screen to specify
the battle type, the map and the funds allowed. The funds
available dictate the size of the armies that players can take into battle.

By clicking the Match Made battle option, we can quickly be paired
up with an opponent of equal skill. We can tailor the

setup here but, for now, let’s find a 1v1 battle opponent by clicking
the Find Match button.

This pre-battle setup screen tells us more about the battle we’re
about to fight. Here we can make last minute tweaks to our

army setup. When we’re done, we’ll click this button to inform
our opponent that we’re ready to go.

Win or lose, our avatar will gain some experience points and eventually
we'll be able to level them up. Having won our previous

battle, we’ve already gained a level, so now we’ve got our first
skill point to spend.

This screen hosts the Avatar skill tree, offering a variety of
upgrades each with unique bonuses. We can roll over a skill to
find out more and left-click to apply it.

The retainer panel displays all the characters and objects available
to us. Retainers can boost our army’s abilities in battle and

also inflict penalties on our enemy. To take a retainer into our
next battle, we simply drag it into one of our empty slots. Right now
we have two slots available, we'll earn more as our Avatar gains levels.

As we win battles, we capture more of the map. Win a province
with a Dojo and we will unlock a new unit type for our army.

There are different Dojos available, each offering a specific unit type,
indicated by their icon. Units unlocked get added to our
roster in the army management panel.

During a battle our units can gain experience. If a unit gains enough
in a single battle, they may reach veteran status. Accepting a

veteran into our army adds them to the veteran unit roster. These
units can then be called into future battles, earn more
experience and be upgraded with new skills.

Veteran units can be customised via the tab on the army management
panel. With our veteran selected, we'll click the customise button.
Now we can name them and play around with their colours.

Clicking the veteran upgrade button will open this panel. Here we
can spend veteran skill points on improving this unit’s abilities.

We left-click an upgrade to apply it. This unit is now more powerful
but will cost us more should we decide to take it into our next battle.

We can continue fighting battles, conquering provinces and
progressing our avatar but let's take things further by playing the
clan competition.

To join a clan we first need to be a member of a Steam Group.
The Clan Page lists all the public Steam Groups open to us and those

we’ve already joined. We simply choose one of our Groups and
label this as our clan.

Clans compete in worlds with 23 others, fighting over possession
of provinces on the Avatar Conquest map. Clans are ranked

according to the number of provinces they control. Owned provinces
are displayed via colour coding on the map. We can view
more details on this province via the tooltips.

Provinces are won by earning Clan Influence. This influence is
increased as clan members earn victories in a province. The control
of surrounding provinces also contributes influence.

The clan leader can mark a province as a priority target for their
members. By winning battles for our clan, we can earn tokens.

These clan tokens can be used to upgrade our veteran units
with new abilities and to reset our avatar skills.

Worlds are arranged in a pyramid system. At the end of a season,
normally a two-week period, the top clans are promoted up the

pyramid. The bottom clans are also relegated down a level before
the next season begins.
